awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Wettability Control on the Mechanics of Fracture in Granular and Porous Media
awd_abstract_narration:
The way that fracture networks develop in granular and porous media is a question of importance to a wide range of applications, ranging from natural gas exploration to the failure of modern fuel cells.  This award will support fundamental studies of how fluid flow can drive the evolution of fracture networks in granular systems.  The inquiry is supported by recent observations indicating that "wettability", a measure of attraction between the fluids and the granular media, may play a vital and previously unexplored role in governing the fracture response.  Insights from this study will help scientists and engineers identify the optimal process conditions to either increase or decrease fracture growth, as desired.  The development of the new experiments and models will also provide training for new doctoral students from under-represented groups, transferring the requisite skills for them to address technologically important and challenging problems in flow-induced fracture. Finally, outreach activities to under-represented minority students in the STEM area are planned as part of this effort through a novel partnership with NC-SLI. In particular, a joint MIT-Duke workshop on emerging research in civil and environmental engineering will be set up to facilitate students from these groups pursuing summer research opportunities in this area.

This project is focused on the morphodynamics of hydrocapillary fracture in granular and porous media with an emphasis on the role of wettability. In particular, it concerns the response of idealized cells that are densely packed with quasi-porous media and saturated with a viscous defending fluid. Observations indicate a surprisingly strong dependence of fracture morphology on wetting properties, even at high injection rates where viscous forces dominate. The main objectives are to significantly advance the current understanding of hydrocapillary fracture, and to develop model-based simulation capabilities that are useful and predictive in this space. This will be effected through the development of an integrated suite of novel experiments and accompanying computational tools that allow emerging models of these systems to be fully explored. This joint effort will allow several open questions to be examined, such as the conditions that promote stable fracturing. A central question this project seeks to answer concerns the apparent "fracture toughness" of granular media, and how such toughness evolves as the media approaches a more conventional poroelastic solid.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
A frontier in the experimental investigation of the interplay between fluid and solid mechanics of granular media is the ability to directly characterize the evolution of stresses, which can be achieved by photoelasticity. In this project, we have been able to manufacture, for the first time, photoelastic beads in milimeter size, making it possible to visualize the force chains evolution under the impact of varying fluid pore pressure. This has led to the development of an altogether new technique, which we have coined photoporomechanics. The wealth of microscopic observables provided by this technology include contact forces, length and orientation of force chains, particle coordination number, which are crucial for gaining a deeper understanding of the hydrocapillary fracturing process in the context of grain-scale mechanics.

 

Using this new photoporomechanics technology, we have developed a novel experimental setup to visualize the evolution of the stress field at the particle level during hydrocapillary fracturing. The experimental system consists in a circular Hele-Shaw (a gap between two parallel transparent plates) packed with a monolayer of several thousand spherical, photoelastic particles. The single-layer granular pack is saturated with a viscous liquid, and another fluid is then injected at the center of the cell into the densely-packed granular assembly and injection pressure is measured through a coaxial needle at the injection port. A dual-camera system is adopted: one camera without polarized filters for brightfield imaging, which captures particles positions and air invasion morphology, the other camera with polarized filters for darkfield imaging, which captures the photoelastic response of the particles and visualizes the stress field.

 

The newly developed experimental technique has enabled the discovery of two different modes of fluid invasion: fracturing in fluid-filled elastic media (with strong photoelastic response), and viscous fingering in frictional fluids (with weak or negligible photoelastic response). We have directly visualized the evolving effective stress field, and discovered an effective stress shadow behind the propagating fracture tips, where the granular pack exhibits undrained behavior. We have conceptualized the system’s behavior by means of a mechanistic model revealing that a jamming transition dictates the distinct rheological behavior from a frictional to an elastic response.

 

We have also introduced a new experimental technique that integrates photoporomechanics into tomography, to observe the temporal evolution of 3D force chains under isotropic compression, triaxial shear and rotary shear. Our experimental study visualizes the alignment and intensification of 3D force chains as the external load changes from isotropic to triaxial shear and rotary shear. We also show that the fluctuation of the continuum-scale shear stresses can be pinpointed to the grain-scale buckling and healing of force chains.

 

The technology developed in this project will likely make an impact on teaching geomechanics and geotechnical engineering, since it allows, for the first time, to visualize the evolution of effective stress in a granular medium. This will facilitate exposition of poroelasticity and consolidation theories which, until now, have been purely theoretical constructs.

 

Given the ubiquitous nature of poromechanics in geological processes, biomechanics, and biotechnology, we anticipate that the experimental technologies developed in this project will make inroads in those fields. For example, the understanding of force chains in granular materials, and their evolution as a result of the coupling with flow, is key to shear banding and failure of concrete structures, and the transition from aseismic slip to stick-slip motion in geological faults—these force chains can now be visualized and quantified when the pore pressure is changing as a result of shear. We also anticipate that the knowledge acquired regarding the evolution of stress around a fracture in a frictional and cohesive granular medium will impact the design of hydraulic fracturing of rocks and the design of earth foundations. It may also impact understanding of fracture processes in bone and cartilaginous tissue.

 

The work performed in this project has resulted in several key outcomes, including 5 papers already published in the peer-reviewed literature (detailed in the project products), several manuscripts in preparation, and several talks on this subject at top scientific conferences like the American Physical Society March Meeting, the American Physical Society DFD meeting, and the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting.

 

The project has provided funding and development opportunities for a graduate student, who completed her PhD at MIT, and a postdoctoral researcher. They both interacted closely with researchers at Duke University, and had the opportunity to give oral presentation at top conferences, like the American Physical Society DFD meeting, and the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, thus broadening their experiences. The visibility of their work in this project has allowed them to secure a postdoc position and a faculty position at top universities, respectively.

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2023
Modified by: Ruben Juanes
